key_channel_insights.line_content: OTAs listed higher fares than Air Serbia’s website in 94.1% of itineraries, while undercuts remained rare at 2.7% and missing listings held at just over 3%.
The MSE channel achieved price parity in 76.3% of itineraries, with discounts in 19.9% and missing offers rising to 3.8%.
GDS fares exceeded the website in 96.77% of origin-destination pairs, with modest discount growth to 2.69% and negligible website-only rates at 0.54%.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: OTA listed higher fares than the website in 94.1% of itineraries last week, though this share declined by 0.5pp week-over-week and 0.8pp month-over-month.
Instances of OTA undercutting the website remain rare at 2.7% of itineraries, but this share grew by 0.23pp week-over-week and 0.85pp month-over-month.
OTA had no matching offers for 3.23% of itineraries last week, marking a modest increase of 0.27pp from the previous week.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: 3.23% of itineraries lacked OTA offers last week, up 0.27pp from the previous week.
94.09% of itineraries displayed OTA prices above the website last week, with an average surcharge of 0.08% and a downward trend of –0.50pp week-over-week and –0.77pp month-over-month.
OTA underpricing occurred in 2.69% of cases last week, offering an average discount of 0.15% and growing by 0.23pp week-over-week and 0.85pp month-over-month.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: In short-haul segments, OTA fares exceeded the website in 94.09% of itineraries by an average of 0.08%, though share fell by 0.50pp week-over-week and 0.77pp month-over-month.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: For RS origins, OTA markups appeared in 94.25% of itineraries at a 0.09% average premium, while undercuts rose to 3.45%—an increase of 1.36pp week-over-week—and offered a 0.19% discount.
In non-RS origins, OTA surcharges occurred in 93.94% of itineraries with a 0.07% premium, and underpricing was observed in 3.03% of cases at a 0.12% average discount.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Close-in bookings saw OTA fares above the website in 92.04% of itineraries, delivering a 0.07% average premium and experiencing a 0.76pp week-over-week decline in share.
Far-out bookings had the highest OTA surcharge prevalence at 97.30% with a 0.09% average premium and minimal week-over-week and month-over-month shifts.

mse_highlights.line_content: In the MSE channel, price parity holds for 76.3% of itineraries last week, marking a 7.2 percentage-point increase versus the prior month.
MSE lower-price occurrences dropped from 29.8% monthly to 19.9% last week, with average discounts narrowing slightly to around 0.11%.
Instances where website offers aren’t found on MSE rose to 3.8% last week, up 2.7 percentage points versus the previous month.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Missing MSE offers increased from 1.1% monthly to 3.8% last week—a 2.7pp rise, signaling growing distribution gaps.
Consistent prices appear in 76.3% of cases last week, a marginal 1.0pp dip from the prior week but a 7.2pp gain versus last month.
Lower MSE prices occurred in 19.9% of itineraries last week, slightly down 0.3pp from the week before and down 9.9pp month-over-month, with average savings at roughly 0.11%.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: Short-haul routes mirror the overall MSE pattern: 76.3% parity, 19.9% discounted with a 0.11% average discount, and 3.8% missing offers.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Flights originating in Serbia show 87.4% price parity last week, only 12.6% discounted with deeper average savings of 0.15%.
Non-Serbian origins exhibit 65.7% parity and a higher 27.3% discounted share, though average discounts are milder at 0.09%.

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Close-in bookings maintain 73.5% parity and 23.0% discounts averaging 0.11%, with missing offers at 3.5% and an 8.1pp parity gain versus last month.
Far-out bookings deliver 79.7% parity and only 16.2% discounts at about 0.10%, with a 4.5pp uptick in discount share versus the prior week.

gds_highlights.line_content: In the latest week, 96.77% of origin-destination pairs on GDS were priced above the website, confirming a uniform markup approach.
Channel-lower fares, although limited to 2.69% of ODs, increased by 0.84pp month-over-month, signaling growing competitiveness.
Average differentials remain minimal—+0.07% for GDS-higher fares and –0.17% for GDS-lower—limiting impact on booking behavior.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Website-exclusive fares account for just 0.54% of ODs, up slightly from 0.38% month-over-month but operationally negligible.
GDS fares exceeded website prices in 96.77% of ODs, marking a 0.27pp decrease week-over-week and stable month-over-month trends.
Channel-lower fares represented 2.69% of ODs, rising 0.23pp week-over-week and 0.84pp month-over-month, highlighting modest growth in discounts.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: Short-haul routes mirror overall trends with 96.77% markup share (–0.27pp week-over-week) and a 2.69% channel-lower share, maintaining average differentials of +0.07%/–0.17%.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: RS-origin itineraries show a 95.45% markup share (–2.44pp week-over-week) with channel-lower deals at 3.41% (+1.30pp) and average differentials of +0.06%/–0.20%.
Non-RS routes sustain a 96.97% markup share (–0.23pp week-over-week) and 3.03% channel-lower share (+0.23pp), with average differentials of +0.07%/–0.13%.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Close-in itineraries carry a 95.54% markup share (+0.26pp week-over-week) and 3.57% markdown share (–0.37pp), with average gaps of +0.06%/–0.16%.
Far-out bookings exhibit the highest markup prevalence at 98.65% (–0.05pp week-over-week) and just 1.35% markdowns, with average differentials of +0.08%/–0.18%.
